dt: {bc}characteristic of only one person, group, or thing {bc}{sx|distinctive||}

dt.t: … a drowsy fervour of manner and tone which was quite {wi}peculiar{/wi} to her.
It seems {wi}peculiar{/wi} that she would leave town without telling anybody.
The play had a zany plot and very {wi}peculiar{/wi} characters.

pt: {sc}characteristic{/sc} {sc}individual{/sc} {sc}peculiar{/sc} {sc}distinctive{/sc} mean indicating a special quality or identity. {sc}characteristic{/sc} applies to something that distinguishes or identifies a person or thing or class.
{sc}individual{/sc} stresses qualities that distinguish one from all other members of the same kind or class.
{sc}peculiar{/sc} applies to qualities possessed only by a particular individual or class or kind and stresses rarity or uniqueness.

pt.t: an eccentricity that is {it}peculiar{/it} to the British

pt: {sc}distinctive{/sc} indicates qualities distinguishing and uncommon and often superior or praiseworthy.

pt.t: a {it}distinctive{/it} aura of grace and elegance

pt: {sc}strange{/sc} {sc}singular{/sc} {sc}unique{/sc} {sc}peculiar{/sc} {sc}eccentric{/sc} {sc}erratic{/sc} {sc}odd{/sc} {sc}quaint{/sc} {sc}outlandish{/sc} mean departing from what is ordinary, usual, or to be expected. {sc}strange{/sc} stresses unfamiliarity and may apply to the foreign, the unnatural, the unaccountable.
{sc}unique{/sc} implies singularity and the fact of being without a known parallel.

pt.t: a career {it}unique{/it} in the annals of science
the {it}peculiar{/it} status of America's First Lady

pt: {sc}eccentric{/sc} suggests a wide divergence from the usual or normal especially in behavior.
{sc}erratic{/sc} stresses a capricious and unpredictable wandering or deviating.
{sc}odd{/sc} applies to a departure from the regular or expected.
{sc}quaint{/sc} suggests an old-fashioned but pleasant oddness.
{sc}outlandish{/sc} applies to what is uncouth, bizarre, or barbaric.

quotes.t: As military coups go, this was a most {qword}peculiar{/qword} one, bloodless, and in Bangkok at least quite popular.
Right about then, Ensberg got himself back on the field, where a {qword}peculiar{/qword} thing happened: he stopped thinking.
I smell again the {qword}peculiar{/qword} and dynamic smell of Gillespie's science room.

et: Middle English {it}peculier{/it}, from Latin {it}peculiaris{/it} of private property, special, from {it}peculium{/it} private property, from {it}pecu{/it} cattle; akin to Latin {it}pecus{/it} cattle {ma}{mat|fee|}{/ma}
shortdef: characteristic of only one person, group, or thing : distinctive
different from the usual or normal:

dt: {bc}a church or {d_link|parish|parish} exempt from the jurisdiction of the {d_link|ordinary|ordinary:2} in whose territory it lies

shortdef: something exempt from ordinary jurisdiction; especially : a church or parish exempt from the jurisdiction of the ordinary in whose territory it lies

dt: {bc}of, relating to, or found in (only one person, thing, or place)

shortdef: of, relating to, or found in (only one person, thing, or place)
